awd_titl_txt: The Effects of Intoxication in Legal Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
Intoxicated suspects in the U.S. are routinely interrogated by law enforcement despite the fact that very little is known about the effects of intoxication in legal contexts. Specifically, how intoxication impacts confession decisions, comprehension of Miranda rights, suggestibility, ability to lie, and behavior during questioning are all unknown. These issues are important, as law enforcement interrogation practices in the U.S. have drawn criticism for their coercive nature and these concerns have been validated by proven cases of false confessions. Of primary concern, alcohol myopia theory suggests that the intoxicated may be at particular risk for making impulsive decisions - focusing on immediate consequences at the expense of consequences in the future. 

The proposed research is the first to address this major research void, examining a) the confession decisions of intoxicated suspects, and b) how intoxicated suspects are perceived by others. Study 1 will investigate the impact of intoxication using an experimental lab paradigm involving the interrogation of guilty and innocent students accused of cheating and will further assess how intoxication impacts suggestibility and Miranda rights comprehension. Study 2 will use Study 1's interrogation videos to examine students' and law enforcements' veracity judgments about true and false confessors and true and false deniers, and the behaviors exhibited in those statements. The current studies will contribute to a growing understanding of intoxication's impact on suspect behavior and interrogation outcomes and will provide the criminal justice and legal communities with tools to improve the gathering and evaluation of suspect statements, creating incentives to adopt evidence-based procedures.

por.por_cntn:
Intoxicated individuals are regularly arrested and questioned by law enforcement and their statements are evaluated by investigators, attorneys, judges, and jurors. This project aimed to examine the impact of suspect intoxication on legally relevant behaviors and decisions, including suspects? interrogative suggestibility, confession decisions, comprehension of Miranda rights, and ability to lie convincingly. Addressing these topics advances knowledge in the fields of investigative interviewing, forensic psychology, decision making, deception detection, criminal justice, and law.

Study 1 began with eligible participants drinking randomly assigned beverages associated with either an intoxication group (aiming for intoxication levels around the U.S. drunk driving limit of .08%), a sober group, or a placebo group. Placebo participants believed they were in the intoxication group, but in fact received only a negligible dose of alcohol.

After drinking their beverages, Study 1 participants completed the Gudjonsson Suggestibility Scale. Suggestibility was measured by examining how often participants went along with leading questions about a story that had been previously read to them, and how often they changed their answers after receiving negative feedback about their initial answers. Intoxication did not impact suggestibility.

Study 1 participants also completed a cheating paradigm that set up only half of the participants to cheat on an experimental task. All participants were then accused of cheating, informed that cheating could be considered academic misconduct, and interrogated with the goal of obtaining a confession. While 88% of intoxicated participants said something that could be considered incriminating (vs. 71% and 65% for the placebo and sober participants respectively), this difference was not statistically significant. Consistent with past research, there was a tendency for participants to say something incriminating when the consequences of confession were described as leading to a short-term benefit (as opposed to a denial leading to short term benefit), with a few exceptions: This pattern did not hold for participants who did not cheat, nor for placebo participants.

Study 1 participants also completed the Miranda Rights Comprehension Instruments. This includes four tests of Miranda rights understanding and appreciation (i.e., right to silence, right to an attorney, right to have an attorney appointed, right to stop questioning at any point, and a warning that any statements made can be used in court). Two of the four instruments indicated that the intoxicated may show reduced comprehension.

Participants in Studies 2 and 3 each viewed six videos of Study 1 participants being interrogated. These videos corresponded to an intoxicated participant, a placebo participant, and a sober participant truly denying cheating, and an intoxicated participant, a placebo participant, and a sober participant falsely denying cheating. In Study 2, all participants learned about 11 evidence-based cues to truth/deception and rated the presence of those cues in each video. They then rated the likelihood that the person being questioned in the video was lying. In Study 3, half the participants did the same thing as the Study 2 participants; the other half did not rate or learn about any cues and simply rated the likelihood that the person in the video was lying. Thus, Study 3 allowed for a test to determine whether paying attention to the cues helped participants detect truths and lies. Participants were more successful at detecting deception when the interviewee was in the intoxication group (vs. sober or placebo groups). Training regarding the cues and rating their presence only improved the ability to detect lies when viewing interviewees from the placebo group.

Regarding intellectual merit, the aforementioned results greatly advance knowledge regarding intoxication?s influence in a variety of contexts in the legal realm. Study 1 provided the first experimental tests of intoxication?s effect on confession decisions and Miranda rights comprehension. Study 1 also offers the first test of the impact of short-term consequences on interrogation behaviors of both guilty and innocent interviewees. Further, Study 1?s findings help to disentangle the inconsistent findings of past research regarding intoxication?s impact on suggestibility. Studies 2 and 3 are the first studies to examine the ability to detect deception in the intoxicated and offer insights into the behaviors that the intoxicated display during interrogation.

Regarding broader impact, this project provided professional development opportunities for five female graduate students, all of whom are/will be authors on at least one paper. Further, over the course of the project, dozens of undergraduate research assistants gained valuable experience working on the project in a variety of roles; one of these research assistants has been included as an author on multiple papers. Most of these research assistants were female and/or Hispanic, and thus belong to groups that are often underrepresented in science. Some of the findings have already been published and presented at conferences, and results will continue to be shared broadly. The findings can inform the way law enforcement interact with intoxicated suspects and how the legal system evaluates statements provided by the intoxicated.
